Creating a Basic For Loop

title: Tidbits
text:
Running Code
When you click the Render button a document will be generated that includes both content and the output of embedded code. You can embed code like this:

1 + 1

[1] 2


You can add options to executable code like this


[1] 4


The echo: false option disables the printing of code (only output is displayed).

title: Creating a Basic For Loop
text:
One of the key tenets of programming is the DRY principle: Don’t Repeat Yourself. Essentially, this boils down to not repeating your code ad nauseum to change only one or two things. This is particularly useful for computationally intensive workflows that would require changing tens or hundreds of items. That’s where the for loop comes into play.
First, let’s look at the basic syntax of a for loop. When you write one, you’re telling the computer “run this piece of code (statement) some number of times (range_of_values) in this spot (value).”






Syntax




for(value in range_of_values){
  statement 
  print(statement) 
}



And that’s it! Congratulations, now you know the syntax for a basic for loop! Now let’s see it in practice. Now let’s put it into practice.






Example



Let’s say Europe is experiencing a heat wave, but I’m not quite grasping the context of how bad it is because I’m not familiar with the Celsius temperature scale. I know the average temperatures are somewhere between 35-40°C, so I’ll write a quick function to convert the temperatures into Fahrenheit! But that spans over five numbers, and writing that function out five individual times goes against the DRY principle. This gives us the perfect excuse to write a for loop.
The equation for converting temperatures from Celsius to Fahrenheit is the following. \[(deg C*1.8) + 32\] Knowing that conversion formula, here’s how I’d write my for loop:

for(degC in 35:40){
  # Write your statement. Make sure the output of the statement is assigned to an object,
  # otherwise R will only remember the very last conversion value. 
  fahr <- (degC*1.8) + 32
  
  # Print the outputs
  print(fahr)
}

[1] 95
[1] 96.8
[1] 98.6
[1] 100.4
[1] 102.2
[1] 104


Yep, that’s pretty toasty!


For more help on for loops and other iterative processes, make sure to check out the R for Data Science book by Hadley Wickham and Garrett Grolemund!

title: Daphne Virlar-Knight
text:
Welcome!
Finley Malloc is the Chief Data Scientist at Wengo Analytics. When not innovating on data platforms, Finley enjoys spending time unicycling and playing with her pet iguana.

My Data Science Journey


Podcast Favorites
I am constantly listening to something. If I’m not listening to music, you can bet I’m listening to a podcast! Below are a few of the ones I listen to regularly, they’re associated genre, and the show’s description from Spotify in case you’re unfamiliar with them.

Up First – News.  NPR’s Up First is the news you need to start your day. The three biggest stories of the day, with reporting and analysis from NPR News — in 10 minutes.
Short Wave – Educational.  New discoveries, everyday mysteries, and the science behind the headlines — all in about 10 minutes, every weekday. It’s science for everyone, using a lot of creativity and a little humor. Join host Emily Kwong for science on a different wavelength.
Life Kit – Lifestyle.  Everyone needs a little help being a human. From sleep to saving money to parenting and more, we talk to the experts to get the best advice out there. Life Kit is here to help you get it together.
Ologies – Educational & Comedy.  Volcanoes. Trees. Drunk butterflies. Mars missions. Slug sex. Death. Beauty standards. Anxiety busters. Beer science. Bee drama. Take away a pocket full of science knowledge and charming, bizarre stories about what fuels these professional -ologists’ obsessions. Humorist and science correspondent Alie Ward asks smart people stupid questions and the answers might change your life.
My Favorite Murder – True Crime & Comedy.  Lifelong fans of true crime stories Karen Kilgariff and Georgia Hardstark tell each other their favorite tales of murder and hear hometown crime stories from friends and fans.
Your Own Backyard – True Crime.  A documentary podcast series investigating the 1996 disappearance of Cal Poly student, Kristin Smart.



YouTube Favorites
When I’m coding I usually need some sort of music playing in the background to help me focus. As such, I’ve found a couple of channels, playlists, and video categories that really help me dial in when I need to.

Luna Ambience – Relaxing music from the “Breath of the Wild” video game
No Thoughts, Head Empty – A collection of videos with various (mostly fast-paced) Nintendo music to help you focus in Fast ModeTM . Don’t ask me how many times I’ve listened to Coconut Mall…
DevAsLife – I enjoy listening to the ASMR-like coding videos on this channel, as well as “watching” them using the picture in picture method.
Study With Me – Many of these videos use the pomodoro technique and have soft music playing in the background. This is non-distracting for me, and has built-in breaks throughout the video. My absolute favorite is currently this “Write With Me” video from Ali Abdaal.
